column1: She married Edwin Horatio Hamilton Seacole in Kingston on 10 November 1836.[58] Her marriage, from betrothal to widowhood, is described in just nine lines at the conclusion of the first chapter of her autobiography.[2] Robinson reports the legend in the Seacole family that Edwin was an illegitimate son of Nelson and his mistress, Emma Hamilton, who was adopted by Thomas, a local "surgeon, apothecary and man midwife"[59] (Seacole's will indicates that Horatio Seacole was Nelson's godson: she left a diamond ring to her friend, Lord Rokeby, "given to my late husband by his godfather Viscount Nelson", but there was no mention of this godson in Nelson's own will or its codicils.)[60] Edwin was a merchant and seems to have had a poor constitution. The newly married couple moved to Black River and opened a provisions store which failed to prosper.
column2: El 1836, es va casar amb Edwin Horatio Hamilton Seacole[1] [2]i es traslladaren a Black River on van obrir una botiga de queviures que no va prosperar.

column1: They returned to Blundell Hall in the early 1840s.
column2: Van tornar a Blundell Hall a principis de la dècada de 1840.

column1: During 1843 and 1844, Seacole suffered a series of personal disasters. She and her family lost much of the boarding house in a fire in Kingston on 29 August 1843.[1] Blundell Hall burned down, and was replaced by New Blundell Hall, which was described as "better than before".[43] Then her husband died in October 1844, followed by her mother.[43] After a period of grief, in which Seacole says she did not stir for days,[2] she composed herself, "turned a bold front to fortune",[43] and assumed the management of her mother's hotel.
column2: Durant 1843 i 1844, Seacole va patir una sèrie de desastres personals.

column1: She put her rapid recovery down to her hot Creole blood, blunting the "sharp edge of [her] grief" sooner than Europeans who she thought "nurse their woe secretly in their hearts".[26]
column2: Un incendi a Kingston va cremar Blundell Hall, i va ser substituït per New Blundell Hall.[1] Llavors en poc temps morí el seu marit i la seva mare. Després d'un període de dol va assumir la gestió de l'hotel de la mare.[1]

column1: Mary Jane Seacole (née Grant;[3][4] 23 November 1805 – 14 May 1881)[5] was a British-Jamaican nurse, healer and businesswoman[6][7][8][9][10] who set up the "British Hotel" behind the lines during the Crimean War.
column2: Mary Jane Seacole, també coneguda com Mary Jane Grant,[1] [2](23 de novembre de 1805-14 de maig de 1881). [3] Va ser una infermera britànica-jamaicana, cuidadora i empresària,[4] [5] [6] que va establir l'Hotel britànic (British Hotel) darrere de les línies durant la Guerra de Crimea.

column1: She described this as "a mess-table and comfortable quarters for sick and convalescent officers", and provided succour for wounded servicemen on the battlefield, and nursed many of them back to health.[4][7][6][11] Coming from a tradition of Jamaican and West African "doctresses", Seacole displayed "compassion, skills and bravery while nursing soldiers during the Crimean War", through the use of herbal remedies.[6][12] She was posthumously awarded the Jamaican Order of Merit in 1991. In 2004, she was voted the greatest black Briton.[13]
column2: Allà proporcionà suport i cures als soldats ferits al camp de batalla.[2] [4][5][7] Hereva de la medicina tradicional jamaicana i d'Àfrica Occidental, Seacole va mostrar "compassió, habilitats i valentia mentre que cuidava els soldats durant la Guerra de Crimea, a través de l'ús de remeis amb plantes medicinals”. [4] [8] Guardonada pòstumament amb l'Orde del Mèrit jamaicà el 1991, el 2004, va ser votada la millor britànica negra.

column1: Seacole absorbed herself in work, declining many offers of marriage.[1] She later became known to the European military visitors to Jamaica who often stayed at Blundell Hall.
column2: Seacole, es concentrà en la seva feina i rebutjà algunes ofertes de matrimoni.[1] La seva feina va ser coneguda pels militars europeus que visitaven Jamaica i que sovint es quedaven a Blundell Hall.

column1: She treated and nursed patients in the cholera epidemic of 1850, which killed some 32,000 Jamaicans.[61][3]
column2: Va tractar i cuidar pacients en l'epidèmia de còlera de 1850, que va matar uns 32.000 jamaicans.[2][3] Llavors es quan adquireix una experiència que li serà útil en el transcurs dels cinc anys posteriors.

column1: In 1850, Seacole's half-brother Edward[62] moved to Cruces, Panama, which was then part of New Granada. There, approximately 45 miles (72 km) up the Chagres River from the coast, he followed the family trade by establishing the Independent Hotel to accommodate the many travellers between the eastern and western coasts of the United States (the number of travellers had increased enormously, as part of the 1849 California Gold Rush[63]). Cruces was the limit of navigability of the Chagres River during the rainy season, which lasts from June to December.[64] Travellers would ride on donkeys approximately 20 miles (32 km) along the Las Cruces trail from Panama City on the Pacific Ocean coast to Cruces, and then 45 miles (72 km) down-river to the Atlantic Ocean at Chagres (or vice versa).[65] In the dry season, the river subsided, and travellers would switch from land to the river a few miles farther downstream, at Gorgona[64] Most of these settlements have now been submerged by Gatun Lake, formed as part of the Panama Canal.
column2: El 1850, el seu germanastre Edward[1] es trasllada a Cruces, Panama, on obre un hotel que acull els viatgers que anaven camí de Califòrnia atrets per la “Febre de l'or”.[2] Per arribar a Califòrnia existia una ruta que consistia a travessar l'istme de Panamà amb mules i canoes .[3]

column1: In 1851, Seacole travelled to Cruces to visit her brother.
column2: El 1851, Seacole va viatjar a Cruces per visitar el seu germà.

column1: Shortly after her arrival, the town was struck by cholera, a disease which had reached Panama in 1849.[66][2] Seacole was on hand to treat the first victim, who survived, which established Seacole's reputation and brought her a succession of patients as the infection spread.
column2: Poc després de la seva arribada, la ciutat va ser colpejada pel còlera, una malaltia que havia arribat a Panamà el 1849.[1] [2] Seacole va tractar la primera víctima que va sobreviure, el que li donà una reputació i que portà una successió de pacients a mesura que la infecció s'estenia.

column1: The rich paid, but she treated the poor for free.[68] Many, both rich and poor, succumbed.
column2: Els rics pagaven, però ella va tractar els pobres de franc. . Molts, rics i pobres, van morir.

column1: She eschewed opium, preferring mustard rubs and poultices, the laxative calomel (mercuric chloride), sugars of lead (lead(II) acetate), and rehydration with water boiled with cinnamon.[66][69] While her preparations had moderate success, she faced little competition, the only other treatments coming from a "timid little dentist",[66] who was an inexperienced doctor sent by the Panamanian government, and the Roman Catholic Church.
column2: Ella va evitar utilitzar l'opi, preferint els cataplasmes de mostassa, el laxant calomel (clorur de mercuri), els sucres d'acetat de plom i la rehidratació amb aigua bullida amb canyella.[1][3]Mentre que els seus remeis van tenir un èxit moderat, es va enfrontar a poca competència, els únics altres tractaments provenien d'un "petit dentista tímid",[1] que era un metge inexpert enviat pel govern de Panamà, i l'Església catòlica romana.

column1: Sketch of Mary Seacole's British Hotel in Crimea, by Lady Alicia Blackwood (1818–1913), a friend of Florence Nightingale's who resided in the neighbouring "Zebra Vicarage"
column2: Esbós del British Hotel de ary Seacole a Crimea, per lady Alicia Blackwood (1818–1913), amiga de Florence Nightingale

column1: The epidemic raged through the population. Seacole later expressed exasperation at their feeble resistance, claiming they "bowed down before the plague in slavish despair".[1] She performed an autopsy on an orphan child for whom she had cared, which gave her "decidedly useful" new knowledge.
column2: Va realitzar una autòpsia en un nen orfe al qual havia cuidat, que li va donar un nou coneixement "decididament útil". Al final d'aquesta epidèmia ella mateixa va contraure el còlera, obligant-la a descansar durant diverses setmanes.

column1: At the end of this epidemic she herself contracted cholera, forcing her to rest for several weeks. In her autobiography, The Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands, she describes how the residents of Cruces responded: "When it became known that their "yellow doctress" had the cholera, I must do the people of Cruces the justice to say that they gave me plenty of sympathy, and would have shown their regard for me more actively, had there been any occasion."[70]
column2: Es va guanyar el reconeixement de tota la població.[1]

column1: Despite the problems of disease and climate, Panama remained the favoured route between the coasts of the United States.
column2: Malgrat els problemes de malalties i clima, Panamà era la ruta preferida entre les costes dels Estats Units.

column1: Seeing a business opportunity, Seacole opened the British Hotel, which was a restaurant rather than an hotel.
column2: En veure una oportunitat de negoci, Seacole va obrir un hotel que després traslladà.

column1: She described it as a "tumble down hut," with two rooms, the smaller one to be her bedroom, the larger one to serve up to 50 diners. She soon added the services of a barber.[1]
column2: Durant un viatge a Jamaica des de Panamá patí una situació de racisme al no permetre-li pujar a un vaixell nord-americà.[1]

column1: Her memoirs state that her own boarding house was full of sufferers and she saw many of them die. Although she wrote, "I was sent for by the medical authorities to provide nurses for the sick at Up-Park Camp," she did not claim to bring nurses with her when she went. She left her sister with some friends at her house, went to the camp (about a mile, or 1.6 km, from Kingston), "and did my best, but it was little we could do to mitigate the severity of the epidemic."[71] However, in Cuba Seacole is remembered with great fondness by those she nursed back to health, where she became known as "the Yellow Woman from Jamaica with the cholera medicine".[74]
column2: De retorn a Jamaica es requerida per l'exercit britànic per atendre malalts de febre groga.[1][2]

column1: Mary Seacole did not have formal British nursing qualifications or training, but relied on her skill and experience as a healer and a doctress from Jamaica.
column2: Mary Seacole va aprendre d'infermeria de manera autodidàctica, posant en pràctica els coneixements de medicina tradicional d'arrel africana, transmesos per la seva mare.

column1: Schools of nursing in England were only set up after the Crimean war, the first being the (Florence) Nightingale Training School, in 1860 at St Thomas' Hospital in London.[1] Seacole was arguably the first nurse practitioner.[2][14]
column2: Les escoles d'infermeria a Gran Bretanya no es van establir fins després de la guerra de Crimea. La primera va ser la Nightingale Training School el 1860 a l'Hospital de St Thomas a Londres.[1] Probablement Mary Seacole pot ser considerada la primera infermera practicant.[2] [3]

column1: Seacole returned to Panama in early 1854 to finalise her business affairs, and three months later moved to the New Granada Mining Gold Company establishment at Fort Bowen Mine some 70 miles (110 km) away near Escribanos.[75] The superintendent, Thomas Day, was related to her late husband. Seacole had read newspaper reports of the outbreak of war against Russia before she left Jamaica, and news of the escalating Crimean War reached her in Panama.
column2: Mary estava a Panamà, on tractava de liquidar els ruïnosos negocis que havia fet associant-se amb un conegut del seu marit, Thomas Day, (ruïnosos perquè havia invertit tot en una mina d'or que la va obligar a travessar la selva en piragua per a descobrir que no hi havia metall per cap part), quan assabenta per la premsa sobre l'esclat de la guerra contra Rússia i les notícies de l'escalada de la Guerra de Crimea.

column1: She determined to travel to England to volunteer as a nurse with experience in herbal healing skills,[75] to experience the "pomp, pride and circumstance of glorious war" as she described it in Chapter I of her autobiography.
column2: Va decidir viatjar a Anglaterra per oferir-se com a infermera amb experiència en la cura amb herbes medicinals,[1] per experimentar la "pompa, orgull i circumstància d'una guerra gloriosa", com ella la va descriure en el capítol de la seva autobiografia.

column1: A part of her reasoning for going to the Crimean was that she knew some of the soldiers that were deployed there.
column2: Una part del seu raonament per anar a Crimea era que coneixia alguns dels soldats que es van desplegar allà.

column1: In her autobiography she explains how she heard of soldiers that she had cared for and nursed back to health in the 97th and 48th regiments were being shipped back to England in preparation for the fighting on the Crimean Peninsula.
column2: En la seva autobiografia explica com va sentir parlar de soldats que havia cuidat en els regiments que eren enviats de tornada a Anglaterra en preparació per als combats a la península de Crimea.

column1: Sketch of Mary Seacole by Crimean war artist William Simpson (1823–1899), c. 1855
column2: Esbós de Mary Seacole per l'artista de guerra William Simpson (1823–1899), c. 1855

column1: The Crimean War lasted from October 1853 until 1 April 1856 and was fought between the Russian Empire and an alliance of the United Kingdom, France, the Kingdom of Sardinia, and the Ottoman Empire.
column2: La Guerra de Crimea va durar des d'octubre de 1853 fins a l'1 d'abril de 1856 i va enfrontar l'Imperi Rus contra una aliança del Regne Unit, França, el Regne de Sardenya i l'Imperi Otomà.

column1: Many thousands of troops from all the countries involved were drafted to the area, and disease broke out almost immediately.
column2: Milers de tropes de tots los països involucrats van ser reclutades i enviades a la zona, i les malalties van esclatar immediatament.

column1: Hundreds perished, mostly from Cholera.
column2: Centenars de persones van morir, principalment de còlera.

column1: Hundreds more would die waiting to be shipped out, or on the voyage.
column2: Centenars més moririen esperant ser enviats fora, o en el viatge.

column1: Their prospects were little better when they arrived at the poorly staffed, unsanitary and overcrowded hospitals which were the only medical provision for the wounded.
column2: Les seves perspectives eren poc millors quan arribaven als hospitals mal dotats de personal, poc saludables i abarrotats que eren l'única provisió mèdica per als ferits.

column1: In Britain, a trenchant letter in The Times on 14 October triggered Sidney Herbert, Secretary of State for War, to approach Florence Nightingale to form a detachment of nurses to be sent to the hospital to save lives.
column2: A la Gran Bretanya, una carta incisiva a The Times el 14 d'octubre va provocar que Sidney Herbert, Secretari d'Estat per a la Guerra, s'apropés a Florence Nightingale per formar un destacament d'infermeres per ser enviades per salvar vides.

column1: Interviews were quickly held, suitable candidates selected, and Nightingale left for Turkey on 21 October.[76]
column2: Les entrevistes es van celebrar ràpidament, els candidats adequats van ser seleccionats, i Nightingale va marxar a Turquia el 21 d'octubre.[1]

column1: Seacole travelled from Navy Bay in Panama to England, initially to deal with her investments in gold-mining businesses.
column2: Mary Seacole va fer el trajecte fins a Anglaterra, amb cartes de recomanació[1] de doctors de Jamaica i de Panamà .

column1: She then attempted to join the second contingent of nurses to the Crimea.
column2: A la seva arribada es presenta al War Office, per ser enviada a Crimea com a infermera de l'exèrcit, però no arriba a ser entrevistada.

column1: She applied to the War Office and other government offices, but arrangements for departure were already underway.
column2: Comença a prendre consciencia dels prejudicis racials. Mary Seacole retrobà a Gran Bretanya el racisme que havia trobat ja a Panamà.

column1: In her memoir, she wrote that she brought "ample testimony" of her experience in nursing, but the only example officially cited was that of a former medical officer of the West Granada Gold-Mining Company. However, Seacole wrote that this was just one of the testimonials she had in her possession.[77] Seacole wrote in her autobiography, "Now, I am not for a single instant going to blame the authorities who would not listen to the offer of a motherly yellow woman to go to the Crimea and nurse her ‘sons’ there, suffering from cholera, diarrhœa, and a host of lesser ills. In my country, where people know our use, it would have been different; but here it was natural enough – although I had references, and other voices spoke for me – that they should laugh, good-naturedly enough, at my offer."[78]
column2: Comprèn que mai serà entrevistada i es preferiran altres candidates.

column1: Seacole finally resolved to travel to Crimea using her own resources and to open the British Hotel.
column2: Mary Seacole es va decidir finalment a viatjar fins a Crimea amb els seus propis recursos, per obrir-hi un British Hotel.

column1: Business cards were printed and sent ahead to announce her intention to open an establishment, to be called the "British Hotel", near Balaclava, which would be "a mess-table and comfortable quarters for sick and convalescent officers".[1] Shortly afterwards, her Caribbean acquaintance, Thomas Day, arrived unexpectedly in London, and the two formed a partnership.
column2: Anuncià la seva arribada imminent, per obrir un lloc per acomodar militars malalts o convalescents.[1] Thomas Day, un conegut del Carib, l'ajudà a reunir mobles i s'embarcà el 27 de gener de 1855 cap a Constantinople 46,48.

column1: They assembled a stock of supplies, and Seacole embarked on the Dutch screw-steamer Hollander on 27 January 1855 on its maiden voyage, to Constantinople.[77][85] The ship called at Malta, where Seacole encountered a doctor who had recently left Scutari. He wrote her a letter of introduction to Nightingale.[86]
column2: En una escala a Malta, Mary Seacole trobà un doctor que acabava de deixar Scutari, i que li escriu una carta de recomanació a l'atenció de Florence Nightingale.[2]

column1: Seacole visited Nightingale at the Barrack Hospital in Scutari, where she asked for a bed for the night. Seacole wrote, "Mrs. B. questions me very kindly, but with the same look of curiosity and surprise. What object has Mrs. Seacole in coming out?
column2: Després de la seva arribada Constantinoble, visità l'hospital de Florence Nightingale a Scutari.

column1: This is the purport of her questions. And I say, frankly, to be of use somewhere; for other considerations I had not, until necessity forced them upon me.
column2: Hi troba entre els pacients moltes cares familiars de les Antilles.

column1: Willingly, had they accepted me, I would have worked for the wounded, in return for bread and water. I fancy Mrs. B— thought that I sought for employment at Scutari, for she said, very kindly – "Miss Nightingale has the entire management of our hospital staff, but I do not think that any vacancy – "[87]
column2: Trobà Florence Nightingale, i li va proposar una vegada de més de treballar per a ella, però sense exit.

column1: Hoping to assist with nursing the wounded on the outbreak of the Crimean War, Seacole applied to the War Office to be included among the nursing contingent but was refused,[15] so she travelled independently and set up her hotel and tended to the battlefield wounded.
column2: A l'esclat de la guerra de Crimea, Seacole va sol·licitar a l'Oficina de Guerra (Office War) ser inclosa entre el contingent d'infermeria, però va ser rebutjada,[1] de manera que hi anà amb els seus propis recursos i va establir el seu hotel, un petit hospital on va atendre i alimentar als ferits en el camp de batalla.

column1: She became popular among service personnel, who raised money for her when she faced destitution after the war.
column2: Es va fer popular entre el personal militar, que va recaptar diners per a ella quan es va enfrontar a la misèria després de la guerra.

column1: After transferring most of her stores to the transport ship Albatross, with the remainder following on the Nonpareil, she set out on the four-day voyage to the British bridgehead into Crimea at Balaclava.[88] Lacking proper building materials, Seacole gathered abandoned metal and wood in her spare moments, with a view to using the debris to build her hotel.
column2: Es dirigeix a Balaklava, just darrera la línia de foc i a prop del campament britànic, on volia construir el seu hotel.

column1: She found a site for the hotel at a place she christened Spring Hill, near Kadikoi, some 3 1⁄2 miles (5.6 km) along the main British supply road from Balaclava to the British camp near Sevastopol, and within a mile of the British headquarters.[89]
column2: Mary Seacole reuní tot el que va poder recuperar per a la construcció d'aquest. Trobà una localització que batejà Spring Hill.[1]

column1: The hotel was completed in July at a total cost of £800. It included a building made of iron, containing a main room with counters and shelves and storage above, an attached kitchen, two wooden sleeping huts, outhouses, and an enclosed stable-yard.[92][93] The building was stocked with provisions shipped from London and Constantinople, as well as local purchases from the British camp near Kadikoi and the French camp at nearby Kamiesch.
column2: El nou British Hotel va obrir al març 1855.

column1: Seacole sold anything – "from a needle to an anchor"—to army officers and visiting sightseers.[92] Meals were served at the Hotel, cooked by two black cooks, and the kitchen also provided outside catering.
column2: L'edifici venia de tot «des de l'agulla fins a l'àncora » als oficials de l'exèrcit i als visitants. També hi servien menjars. Molts clients compraven a crèdit, la qual cosa li plantejarà problemes més tard.[1]

column1: Despite constant thefts, particularly of livestock, Seacole's establishment prospered. Chapter XIV of Wonderful Adventures describes the meals and supplies provided to officers.
column2: Malgrat els robatoris freqüents, en particular de provisions, l'establiment era pròsper.

column1: They were closed at 8 pm daily and on Sundays. Seacole did some of the cooking herself: "Whenever I had a few leisure moments, I used to wash my hands, roll up my sleeves, and roll out pastry."
column2: L'hotel estava obert sis dies per setmana i tancat el diumenge, i Mary Seacole havia pogut inscriure's en una mena de rutina.

column1: When called to "dispense medications," she did so.[94] Soyer was a frequent visitor, and praised Seacole's offerings,[95] noting that she offered him champagne on his first visit.[3]
column2: Obria d'hora per servir els cafès del matí i a continuació dispensar les cures als pacients.[1]

column1: Map illustrating Mary Seacole's involvement in the Crimean War
column2: El mapa que il·lustra la implicació de Mary Seacole a la guerra de Crimea

column1: Seacole often went out to the troops as a sutler,[99] selling her provisions near the British camp at Kadikoi, and nursing casualties brought out from the trenches around Sevastopol or from the Tchernaya valley.[2] She was widely known to the British Army as "Mother Seacole".[3]
column2: Mary s'acostava fins a les trinxeres per vendre té, llimonada o tabac i fent cures quan era necessari.[1] L'exèrcit britànic la coneixia sota el nom de « Mare Seacole »4.

column1: Apart from serving officers at the British Hotel, Seacole also provided catering for spectators at the battles, and spent time on Cathcart's Hill, some 3 1⁄2 miles (5.6 km) north of the British Hotel, as an observer.
column2: Florence Nightingale sempre es mostrà ambivalent en els seus comentaris respecte la tasca de Mary Seacole, segons es desprèn de la correspondència que es conserva. El British Hotel venia l'alcohol, i acollia també bé viatgers i soldats, la qual cosa va conduir a Nightingale a acusar més tard Seacole de portar un establiment de dubtosa moralitat.

column1: On one occasion, attending wounded troops under fire, she dislocated her right thumb, an injury which never healed entirely.[100] In a dispatch written on 14 September 1855, William Howard Russell, special correspondent of The Times, wrote that she was a "warm and successful physician, who doctors and cures all manner of men with extraordinary success.
column2: Alguns anys més tard, en una carta adreçada l'any 1870 al seu cunyat, Sir Harry Verney, escriu: “[Mary Seacole] guardava - no diria una mala casa – però no pas lluny, durant la guerra de Crimea. [...] era veritablement amable amb els homes, i en particular amb els oficials, els ha fet bé” 58. Més tard, en una segona carta, va més lluny, declarant que Mary Seacole ”era una dona de mal caràcter”, que guardava una “mala casa” 58, és a dir un prostíbul.

column1: She is always in attendance near the battlefield to aid the wounded and has earned many a poor fellow's blessing."
column2: Aquets comentaris potser són únicament del sentiment de superioritat social de Nightingale 58.

column1: Russell also wrote that she "redeemed the name of sutler", and another that she was "both a Miss Nightingale and a [chef]".
column2: En efecte, quan les infermeres d'aquesta última eren enviades a l'hospital Land Transport, al costat del British Hotel, tenien ordre d'evitar tot contacte amb l'establiment i Mary Seacole 59.

column1: Seacole made a point of wearing brightly coloured, and highly conspicuous, clothing—often bright blue, or yellow, with ribbons in contrasting colours.[101][102] While Lady Alicia Blackwood later recalled that Seacole had "... personally spared no pains and no exertion to visit the field of woe, and minister with her own hands such things as could comfort or alleviate the suffering of those around her; freely giving to such as could not pay ...".[103]
column2: Tanmateix, una carta datada del 30 de juny de 1856 de John Hall, inspector general dels hospitals, subratlla la seva gratitud cap a Mary Seacole per a la seva ajuda. 60. Malgrat tot, quan Seacole va arruinar-se després de la guerra, Florence Nightingale va estar un dels donants anònims de la Seacole's Testimonial Fund.

column1: In 1857 a four-day Fundraising Gala took place on the banks of the river Thames, to honour of Mary Seacole.
column2: El 1857 va tenir lloc una gala de quatre dies a la vora del Tàmesi, per honorar a Mary Seacole.

column1: Crowds of about 80,000 attended, including veterans and their families as well as Royalty.
column2: Van assistir unes 80.000 persones, inclosos veterans i les seves famílies, així com la reialesa.

column1: Peace talks began in Paris in early 1856, and friendly relations opened between the Allies and the Russians, with a lively trade across the River Tchernaya.[111] The Treaty of Paris was signed on 30 March 1856, after which the soldiers left Crimea.
column2: El 1856 s'inicien a París les negociacions de pau. Amb la retirada dels soldats de Crimea. Mary Seacole s'enfrontà a un situació financera difícil, d'un costat els soldats marxen, deixant els seus deutes impagats, de l'altre els encàrrecs fets als proveïdors li van arribant i els creditors demanen ser pagats.

column1: Seacole was bankrupt on her return to London.
column2: Seacole es declarà en fallida al retornar a Londres.

column1: Queen Victoria's nephew Count Gleichen (above) had become a friend of Seacole's in Crimea. He supported fund-raising efforts on her behalf.
column2: El comte de Gleichen nebot, de la reina Victòria, (a dalt) hi havia esdevingut amic seu a Crimea i va donar suport a diverses iniciatives a favor seu.

column1: After the end of the war, Seacole returned to England destitute and in poor health.
column2: A la seva tornada a Anglaterra, Mary Seacole està en fallida i en malalta.

column1: In the conclusion to her autobiography, she records that she "took the opportunity" to visit "yet other lands" on her return journey, although Robinson attributes this to her impecunious state requiring a roundabout trip. She arrived in August 1856 and opened a canteen with Day at Aldershot, but the venture failed through lack of funds.[119] She attended a celebratory dinner for 2,000 soldiers at Royal Surrey Gardens in Kennington on 25 August 1856, at which Nightingale was chief guest of honour. Reports in The Times on 26 August and News of the World on 31 August indicate that Seacole was also fêted by the huge crowds, with two "burly" sergeants protecting her from the pressure of the crowd.
column2: Arribà a l'agost 1856, i va considerar d'obrir una botiga amb Thomas Day a Aldershot (Hampshire), però res no es concretà.

column1: However, creditors who had supplied her firm in Crimea were in pursuit. She was forced to move to 1, Tavistock Street, Covent Garden in increasingly dire financial straits.
column2: Va assistir amb 2000 soldats a una celebració donada el 25 d'agost de 1856 en l'honor de Florence Nightingale a Kennington als jardins Reials de Surrey.

column1: The Bankruptcy Court in Basinghall Street declared her bankrupt on 7 November 1856.[120] Robinson speculates that Seacole's business problems may have been caused in part by her partner, Day, who dabbled in horse trading and may have set up as an unofficial bank, cashing debts.[121]
column2: Segons The Times[1] i News of the World[2] Mary Seacole va ser calorosament rebuda per la multitud, acompanyada de dos sergents que la protegien de la pressió de la multitud.

column1: After her death she was largely forgotten for almost a century, but was subsequently recognised for her success as a woman.[16][17] Her autobiography, Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands (1857), is one of the earliest autobiographies of a mixed-race woman, although some aspects of its accuracy have been questioned by present-day supporters of Florence Nightingale.
column2: Després de la seva mort va caure en l'oblit durant gairebé un segle, per posteriorment ser reconeguda per les fites que va aconseguir com a dona.[1][2] La seva autobiografia, Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands (1857), és una de les primeres autobiografies d'una dona mestissa, tot i que l'exactitud d'alguns aspectes que exposa han estat qüestionats pels actuals partidaris de Florence Nightingale.

column1: The erection of a statue of her at St Thomas' Hospital, London, on 30 June 2016, describing her as a "pioneer",[18] has generated controversy and opposition from Nightingale enthusiasts, such as Lynn McDonald, and others researching the period.[19][20][21][22]
column2: La construcció d'una estàtua d'ella a St Thomas' Hospital de Londres, el 30 de juny de 2016, descrivint-la com a infermera pionera,[3] ha generat controvèrsia i oposició entre els partidaris de Nightingale, com Lynn McDonald, i altres que investiguen el període.[4][5][6][7]

column1: At about this time, Seacole began to wear military medals.
column2: En aquesta època, Seacole va començar a portar medalles militars.

column1: These are mentioned in an account of her appearance in the bankruptcy court in November 1856.[122] A bust by George Kelly, based on an original by Count Gleichen from around 1871, depicts her wearing four medals, three of which have been identified as the British Crimea Medal, the French Légion d'honneur and the Turkish Order of the Medjidie medal. Robinson says that one is "apparently" a Sardinian award (Sardinia having joined Britain and France in supporting Turkey against Russia in the war).[122] The Jamaican Daily Gleaner stated in her obituary on 9 June 1881 that she had also received a Russian medal, but it has not been identified. However, no formal notice of her award exists in the London Gazette, and it seems unlikely that Seacole was formally rewarded for her actions in Crimea; rather, she may have bought miniature or "dress" medals to display her support and affection for her "sons" in the Army.[122][123]
column2: Sembla que li van otorgar quatre: la British Crimea Medal, la Légion d'honneur francesa i la Turkish Order of the Medjidie a més d'una de Sardenya.

column1: Seacole's plight was highlighted in the British press.[1] As a consequence a fund was set up, to which many prominent people donated money, and on 30 January 1857, she and Day were granted certificates discharging them from bankruptcy.[124] Day left for the Antipodes to seek new opportunities,[125] but Seacole's funds remained low. She moved from Tavistock Street to cheaper lodgings at 14 Soho Square in early 1857, triggering a plea for subscriptions from Punch on 2 May.[126] However, in Punch's 30 May edition, she was heavily criticised for a letter she sent begging her favorite magazine, which she claimed to have often read to her British Crimean War patients, to assist her in gaining donations. After quoting her letter in full the magazine provides a satiric cartoon of the activity she describes, captioned "Our Own Vivandière," describing Seacole as a female sutler.
column2: Tanmateix les seves dificultats financeres s'agreugen, és perseguida pels creditors del hotel de Crimea.

column1: The article observes: "It will be evident, from the foregoing, that Mother Seacole has sunk much lower in the world, and is also in danger of rising much higher in it, than is consistent with the honour of the British army, and the generosity of the British public." While urging the public to donate, the commentary's tone can be read as ironic: "Who would give a guinea to see a mimic-sutler woman, and a foreigner, frisk and amble about on the stage, when he might bestow the money on a genuine English one, reduced to a two-pair back, and in imminent danger of being obliged to climb into an attic?"[127]
column2: El trist destí de Mary Seacole apareix en la premsa britànica i el Punch va llançar una subscripció pública per ajudar-la.

column1: Mary Seacole, depicted as an admirer of Punch along with her British Crimean War patients in "Our Own Vivandière" (Punch, 30 May 1857).
column2: Mary Seacole, amb un dels seus pacients a la guerra de Crimea (Punch, 30 de maig de 1857).

column1: It became insolvent immediately after the festival, and as a result Seacole only received £57, one quarter of the profits from the event. When eventually the financial affairs of the ruined Company were resolved, in March 1858, the Indian Mutiny was over.[131] Writing of his 1859 journey to the West Indies, the British novelist Anthony Trollope described visiting Mrs. Seacole's sister's hotel in Kingston in his The West Indies and the Spanish Main (Chapman & Hall, 1850). Besides remarking on the pride of the servants and their firm insistence that they be treated politely by guests, Trollope remarked that his hostess, "though clean and reasonable in her charges, clung with touching tenderness to the idea that beefsteak and onions, and bread and cheese and beer, comprised the only diet proper to an Englishman."[132]
column2: Al maig 1857 considerà de marxar a Índia per administrar cures als ferits de la revolució índia de 1857 Indian Rebellion of 1857, però al final va haver de desistir.

column1: She avoids mention of the names of her parents and precise date of birth. In the first chapter, she talks about how her practice of medicine began on animals, such as cats and dogs. Most of the animals caught diseases from their owners, and she would cure them with homemade remedies.
column2: Al juliol 1857, publicà una autobiografia explicant els seus viatges: Wonderful Adventures of Mrs.

column1: A short final "Conclusion" deals with her return to England, and lists supporters of her fund-raising effort, including Rokeby, Prince Edward of Saxe-Weimar, the Duke of Wellington, the Duke of Newcastle, William Russell, and other prominent men in the military. Also within the Conclusion, she describes all of her career adventures experienced in the Crimean War as pride and pleasure.The book was dedicated to Major-General Lord Rokeby, commander of the First Division. In a brief preface, the Times correspondent William Howard Russell wrote, "I have witnessed her devotion and her courage ... and I trust that England will never forget one who has nursed her sick, who sought out her wounded to aid and succour them and who performed the last offices for some of her illustrious dead."[137][138]
column2: Es tractava de la primera autobiografia escrita per una dona negra a Gran Bretanya 85.

column1: One of two known photographs of Mary Seacole, taken for a carte de visite by Maull & Company in London (c. 1873)
column2: Un de dues fotografies conegudes de Mary Seacole, de Maull & Company de Londres (c. 1873)

column1: Seacole joined the Roman Catholic Church circa 1860, and returned to a Jamaica[140] changed in her absence as it faced economic downturn.[141] She became a prominent figure in the country.
column2: Mary Seacole s'uneix a l'església catòlica cap a 1860[1] i tornà a Jamaïca 90, L'any 1867, va patir de nou dificultats financeres, i la Seacole's Testimonial Fund a Londres ressuscità per ajudar-la.

column1: By 1870, Seacole was back in London, living at 40 Upper Berkley St., St. Marylebone.[143] Robinson speculates that she was drawn back by the prospect of rendering medical assistance in the Franco-Prussian War.[144] It seems likely that she approached Sir Harry Verney (the husband of Florence Nightingale's sister Parthenope) Member of Parliament for Buckingham who was closely involved in the British National Society for the Relief of the Sick and Wounded.
column2: L'any 1870, Mary Seacole tornà a Londres. Els seus projectes són confusos, se sap que la seva vinguda havia suscitat intercanvis de correu entre Florence Nightingale i el seu cunyat, Sir Harry Verney (espòs de Parthénope, la germana de F. Nightingale); se suposa doncs que s'havia apropat a aquest últim.

column1: It was at this time Nightingale wrote her letter to Verney insinuating that Seacole had kept a "bad house" in Crimea, and was responsible for "much drunkenness and improper conduct".[145]
column2: S'ha plantejat que potser amb la idea de proposar els seus serveis en la guerra franco-prussiana 93

column1: In London, Seacole joined the periphery of the royal circle. Prince Victor (a nephew of Queen Victoria; as a young Lieutenant he had been one of Seacole's customers in Crimea)[1] carved a marble bust of her in 1871 that was exhibited at the Royal Academy summer exhibition in 1872. Seacole also became personal masseuse to the Princess of Wales who suffered with white leg and rheumatism.[146]
column2: A Londres, Mary Seacole va treballar per la família reial com a massatgista a partir de les coneixences fetes a Crimea

column1: In the census of 3 April 1881, Seacole is listed as a boarder at 3 Cambridge Street, Paddington.[147] Seacole died on 14 May 1881 at her home, 3 Cambridge Street (later renamed Kendal Street) in Paddington, London;[148] the cause of death was noted as "apoplexy". She left an estate valued at more than £2,500. After some specific legacies, many of exactly 19 guineas, the main beneficiary of her will was her sister, (Eliza) Louisa.[149] Lord Rokeby, Colonel Hussey Fane Keane, and Count Gleichen (three trustees of her Fund) were each left £50; Count Gleichen also received a diamond ring, said to have been given to Seacole's late husband by Lord Nelson.[150] A short obituary was published in The Times on 21 May 1881.
column2: Mary Seacole morí l'any 1881 en el seu domicili de Paddington, a Londres 96, d'apoplexia segons els informes de defuncions.

column1: Plaque commemorating Mary Seacole at 14 Soho Square, London W1.
column2: Placa conmemorativa a 14 Soho Square a Londres, a la casa on va viure Mary Seacole

column1: Mary Jane Seacole was born Mary Jane Grant in Kingston, in the Colony of Jamaica,[23] the daughter of James Grant, a Scottish[24][25] Lieutenant in the British Army,[26] and a free Jamaican woman.
column2: Mary Jane Seacole va néixer a Kingston, a la colònia britànica de Jamaica,[1][2] filla de James Grant, un tinent escocès[3], a l'exèrcit britànic,[4] i una dona jamaicana criolla.

column1: Her mother, Mrs Grant, nicknamed "The Doctress", was a healer who used traditional Caribbean and African herbal medicines.
column2: La seva mare, la senyora Grant, coneguda com "The Doctress" (guérisseuse, en crioll jamaicà), era una cuidadora que utilitzava medicina tradicional del Carib i l'Àfrica Oriental.

column1: Mrs Grant also ran Blundell Hall, a boarding house at 7 East Street, which was considered one of the best hotels in all of Kingston.[27][28]
column2: La senyora Grant també va dirigir Blundell Hall, una pensió familiar al 7th East Street ,que era considerat un dels millors hotels de tot Kingston.[5][6] Molts dels que s'hi allotjaven eren soldats o mariners europeus malalts, la majoria de la febre groga endèmica.

column1: By the 21st century, Seacole was much more prominent.
column2: Encara que hagués estat reconeguda al final de la seva vida, Mary Seacole va ser oblidada ràpidament. El seu treball a Crimea fou eclipsat per Florence Nightingale durant molt de temps.

column1: Several buildings and entities, mainly connected with health care, were named after her.
column2: Tanmateix, aquests últims anys s'ha recuperat l'interès per a ella i s'han fet esforços per donar a coneixer millor les seves accions. Seacole ha esdevingut un símbol de les actituds racials i de les injustícies socials a Gran Bretanya en el transcurs d'aquest període.

column1: In 2005, British politician Boris Johnson wrote of learning about Seacole from his daughter's school pageant and speculated: "I find myself facing the grim possibility that it was my own education that was blinkered."[160] In 2007 Seacole was introduced into the National Curriculum, and her life story is taught at many primary schools in the UK alongside that of Florence Nightingale.[2]
column2: És citada per exemple com una “negra oculta de la historia” en els Versicles satànics de Salman Rushdie com Olaudah Equiano: “Veieu, heus aquí Mary Seacole, que ha fet a Crimea tant com una altra senyora de llum màgica, però sent negra, a penes podia ser vista amb la flama de la llàntia de Florence” 99,100. Actualment, enre altres accions, les cases de Londres en les quals havia viscut tenen plaques commemoratives, (a 157 Georges Street , 147 Georges Street, 14 Soho Square). Hi ha una estàtua de Mary Seacole, feta per Martin Jennings (2016), a l'hospital Sant Thomas.

column1: Ward named after Mary Seacole in Whittington Hospital in North London
column2: Pabelló Mary Seacole al Whittington Hospital de Londres

column1: Statue of Mary Seacole at St Thomas' Hospital, London, by Martin Jennings
column2: Estàtua de Mary Seacole a St Thomas'Hospital , Londres, per Martin Jennings

column1: Silvia Federici argues that in the 16th and 17th centuries, European ruling elites carried out witch-hunts that in effect destroyed the folk medicine practised by working-class white women.[29] In contrast, Jamaican doctresses mastered folk medicine, had a vast knowledge of tropical diseases, and had a general practitioner's skill in treating ailments and injuries, acquired from having to look after the illnesses of fellow slaves on sugar plantations.[30] The role of a doctress in Jamaica was a mixture of a nurse, midwife, masseuse and herbalist, drawing strongly on the traditions of Creole medicine.[3] Other notable Jamaican doctresses, who practised good hygiene and the use of herbal remedies in 18th-century Jamaica included, alongside Mrs Grant, Cubah Cornwallis, Sarah Adams and Grace Donne, who nursed and cared for Jamaica's wealthiest planter, Simon Taylor.[31] They practised the use of good hygiene a century before Florence Nightingale wrote about its importance in her book Notes on Nursing.
column2: En els segles XVI i XVII, les elits dirigents europees van destruir la medicina popular que havien practicat les dones blanques de classe treballadora.[1] En canvi, les doctress jamaicanes al segle XVIII encara dominaven la medicina popular i tenien un vast coneixement de les malalties tropicals i del seu tractament.[2] El paper d'una doctress jamaicana era una barreja d'infermera, llevadora, massatgista i remeiera o herbolària, que promovia la bona higiene, ventilació, confort (warmth), hidratació, descans, empatia, bona alimentació i atenció als moribunds.[3] Al costat de la senyora Grant, altres dones com Cubah Cornwallis, Sarah Adams i Grace Donne, cuidaven als esclaus a les plantacions més importants de Jamaica,[4] un segle abans que Florence Nightingale escrivís sobre la importància de la higiene en el seu llibre Notes on Nursing.

column1: Seacole's recognition has been controversial. It has been argued that she has been promoted at the expense of Florence Nightingale.[1] Sociology professor Lynn McDonald has written that "...support for Seacole has been used to attack Nightingale's reputation as a pioneer in public health and nursing."[184] There was opposition to the siting of a statue of Mary Seacole at St Thomas' Hospital on the grounds that she had no connection with this institution, whereas Florence Nightingale did. Dr Sean Lang has stated that she "does not qualify as a mainstream figure in the history of nursing",[185] while a letter to The Times from the Florence Nightingale Society and signed by members including historians and biographers asserted that "Seacole's battlefield excursions ... took place post-battle, after selling wine and sandwiches to spectators.
column2: Però malgrat, tot, encara avui el reconeixement de Seacole és controvertit.

column1: Mrs Seacole was a kind and generous businesswoman, but was not a frequenter of the battlefield "under fire" or a pioneer of nursing."[186] An article by Lynn McDonald in The Times Literary Supplement asked "How did Mary Seacole come to be viewed as a pioneer of modern nursing?", comparing her unfavourably with Kofoworola Pratt who was the first black nurse in the NHS, and concluded "She deserves much credit for rising to the occasion, but her tea and lemonade did not save lives, pioneer nursing or advance health care".[187]
column2: Mentre la professora de sociologia Lynn McDonald[1] ha escrit que "...el suport a Seacole s'ha utilitzat per atacar la reputació de Nightingale com a pionera en salut pública i infermeria.". [2] Martin Jenning i Gretchen Gerzina[3] han suggerit que el color de la pell de Seacole ha jugat un paper important en la resistència d'alguns dels seguidors de Nightingale a reconèixer-la.[4]

column1: Angela Steinmüller (born 15 April 1941, in Schmalkalden) is a German mathematician and science fiction author.[1] Together with her husband Karlheinz Steinmüller she has written science fiction short stories and novels that depict human development on a cosmic scale, grounded in an analysis of social structures and mechanisms.
column2: Angela Steinmüller (Schmalkalden, 15 d'abril de 1941) és una matemàtica alemanya i autora de ciència ficció. [1] Juntament amb el seu marit Karlheinz Steinmüller, ha escrit contes i novel·les de ciència ficció que representen el desenvolupament humà a escala còsmica, fonamentats en una anàlisi d'estructures i mecanismes socials. Angela i Karlheinz Steinmüller no només es trobaven entre els autors més llegits a la RDA, situant-se al capdavant d'una enquesta de 1989 sobre els autors de ciència ficció més populars de la RDA, [2] però les seves obres continuen publicant-se de nou.

column1: Angela and Karlheinz Steinmüller were not only among the most widely read authors in the GDR, ranking at the top of a 1989 poll of most popular science fiction authors in the GDR,[2] but their works continue to be republished.
column2: Va estudiar 1971 a 1975: Matemàtiques a la Universitat Humboldt de Berlín. A partir del 1980 va decidir convertir-se en escriptora independent. Angela i Karlheinz Steinmüller han estat escrivint treballs conjunts i treballs propis des de fa molts anys.

column1: 1993: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Best short story" for Der Kerzenmacher 1995: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Best short story" for Leichter als Vakuum (with Karlheinz Steinmüller und Erik Simon) 2001: German Fantasy Prize for die Verbreitung der phantastischen Literatur in zwei verschiedenen Gesellschaftssystemen sowie ihre Zukunftsperspektiven. (with Karlheinz Steinmüller) 2004: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Best short story" for Vor der Zeitreise (with Karlheinz Steinmüller)
column2: 1993: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Millor relat curt" per Der Kerzenmacher 1995: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Millor relat" per a Leichter als Vakuum (amb Karlheinz Steinmüller i Erik Simon ) 2001: Premi alemany de fantasia per Die Verbreitung der phantastischen Literatur in zwei verschiedenen Gesellschaftssystemen sowie ihre Zukunftsperspektiven. (amb Karlheinz Steinmüller) 2004: Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis "Millor relat curt" per a Vor der Zeitreise (amb Karlheinz Steinmüller)

column1: Roman eines Planeten, 1986 Der Traummeister, 1990 Spera, 2004
column2: Roman eines Planeten , 1986 Der Traummeister, 1990 Spera, 2004

column1: Abitur (German: [abiˈtuːɐ̯]) is a qualification granted at the end of secondary education in Germany, Lithuania, and Estonia.
column2: Abitur ( German: [abiˈtuːɐ̯] ) és una titulació atorgada al final de l'educació secundària a Alemanya, Lituània i Estònia .

column1: It is conferred on students who pass their final exams at the end of ISCED 3, usually after twelve or thirteen years of schooling (see also, for Germany, Abitur after twelve years).
column2: Es confereix als estudiants que passen els exàmens finals al final de la CINE 3, normalment després de dotze o tretze anys d'escolarització (vegeu també, per a Alemanya, Abitur després de dotze anys ).

column1: In German, the term Abitur has roots in the archaic word Abiturium, which in turn was derived from the Latin abituruscode: lat promoted to code: la (future active participle of abirecode: lat promoted to code: la , thus "someone who is going to leave").
column2: En alemany, el terme Abitur té arrels en la paraula arcaica Abiturium , que al seu torn derivava del llatí abiturus (futur participi actiu d ' abire , per tant, "algú que marxarà"). Com a examen de matrícula, Abitur es pot comparar amb els nivells A, el Matura o el Diploma Internacional de Batxillerat, que es classifiquen com a nivell 4 en el marc europeu de qualificacions .

column1: The academic level of the Abitur is comparable to the International Baccalaureate, the GCE Advanced Level and the Advanced Placement tests.
column2: El nivell acadèmic d' Abitur és comparable al Batxillerat Internacional, el Nivell Avançat GCE i les proves de Col·locació Avançada . De fet, els requisits d'estudi per al batxillerat internacional difereixen poc dels requisits de l'examen alemany.

column1: Indeed, the study requirements for the International Baccalaureate differ little from the German exam requirements.
column2: És l'únic certificat d'abandonament escolar de tots els estats d'Alemanya que permet al graduat (o Abiturient ) traslladar-se directament a la universitat . La resta de certificats d'abandonament escolar, el Hauptschulabschluss i el Realschulabschluss, no permeten als seus titulars matricular-se a una universitat. Els certificats concedits de Hauptschulabschluss o Realschulabschluss poden obtenir una Fachhochschulreife especialitzada o un Abitur si es graduen en una Berufsschule i després assisteixen a Berufsoberschule o es graduen en una Fachoberschule .

column1: It is the only school-leaving certificate in all states of Germany that allows the graduate (or Abiturient) to move directly to university.
column2: Tanmateix, l' Abitur no és l'únic camí cap als estudis universitaris, ja que algunes universitats organitzen les seves pròpies proves d'accés. Els estudiants que hagin superat amb èxit un "Begabtenprüfung" ("prova d'aptitud") també són elegibles.

column1: The other school leaving certificates, the Hauptschulabschluss and the Realschulabschluss, do not allow their holders to matriculate at a university. Those granted certificates of Hauptschulabschluss or Realschulabschluss can gain a specialized Fachhochschulreife or an Abitur if they graduate from a Berufsschule and then attend Berufsoberschule or graduate from a Fachoberschule.
column2: Els estudiants d'altres països que tinguin un certificat d'abandonament escolar que no es consideri equivalent a l' Abitur (com el diploma nord-americà de batxillerat) i que tinguin prou resultats a la prova ACT o SAT, també poden entrar a les universitats alemanyes. Una persona que no tingui l' Abitur i no faci una prova d'aptitud pot continuar sent admesa a la universitat completant almenys el 10è grau i fent un bon examen de QI (vegeu: Hochbegabtenstudium ).

column1: In German, the European Baccalaureate is called europäisches Abitur, and the International Baccalaureate is called internationales Abitur, both not to be confused with the German Abitur.
column2: El Fachabitur també permet que el graduat comenci a estudiar a una universitat, però es limita a una gamma específica de majors, en funció de les assignatures específiques que es tractin en els seus exàmens de Fachabitur. Però al graduat se li permet estudiar per a totes les especialitats en una Fachhochschule (Universitat de Ciències Aplicades, en certa manera comparable a la politècnica ). Avui, el certificat d'abandonament escolar s'anomena fachgebundenes Abitur ("assignatura restringida Abitur") .

column1: Now the term Fachabitur is used in most parts of Germany for the Fachhochschulreife (FHR).
column2: Ara el terme Fachabitur s'utilitza a la majoria de zones d'Alemanya per a la Fachhochschulreife (FHR) . Es va introduir a l'Alemanya Occidental als anys setanta juntament amb el Fachhochschulen . Permet al graduat començar a estudiar a una Fachhochschule i, a Hesse, també a una universitat d'aquest estat.

column1: It was introduced in West Germany in the 1970s together with the Fachhochschulen.
column2: Tot i això, la forma normal d'obtenir Fachhochschulreife és la graduació d'una Fachoberschule alemanya, una escola professional professional, també introduïda als anys setanta. El terme Notabitur (" Abitur d' emergència") descriu una qualificació utilitzada només durant la Primera Guerra Mundial i la Segona Guerra Mundial . Es va concedir als estudiants masculins del Gimnàs alemany que es van alistar voluntàriament per al servei militar abans de graduar-se, així com a les dones joves que van ser evacuades de les principals ciutats abans de poder completar els estudis del Gimnàs tal com estava previst (aproximadament de tres a cinc milions de nens i adolescents van haver de ser evacuats durant la guerra ).

column1: It enables the graduate to start studying at a Fachhochschule and, in Hesse, also at a university within that state.
column2: El Notabitur durant la Primera Guerra Mundial va incloure un examen, aproximadament equivalent a l'examen Abitur. El Notabitur de la Segona Guerra Mundial, en canvi, es va concedir sense examen.

column1: In the Gymnasiums of some states it is awarded in the year before the Abitur is reached.
column2: Després de la guerra, això suposava un desavantatge important per als estudiants afectats, ja que, a diferència del seu homòleg de la Primera Guerra Mundial, el certificat no es reconeixia generalment a Alemanya Occidental i mai a Alemanya Oriental . Les universitats van sol·licitar que l' Abitur consistís en exàmens escrits que incloguessin almenys dues llengües estrangeres (gairebé sempre el llatí i el francès, aquest últim de vegades substituït per l'anglès). Als estudiants, que van rebre el Notabitur durant la Segona Guerra Mundial, se'ls va proposar tornar a entrar a l'escola per preparar-se i presentar-se a l'examen un cop acabada la guerra.

column1: However, the normal way to obtain Fachhochschulreife is graduation from a German Fachoberschule, a vocational high school, also introduced in the 1970s.
column2: Aquestes classes especials de preparació d'Abitur estaven formades per adults joves de diferents edats i sexes, cosa que era molt inusual en aquell moment.

column1: The equivalent graduation certificate in the Czech Republic, Austria, Poland and other countries of continental Europe is the Matura; while in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, Hong Kong, Singapore, and the West Indies, it is A-levels; in Scotland it is Higher Grade; in the Republic of Ireland it is the Leaving Certificate; in Greece and Cyprus it is the "apolytirion" (a kind of high school diploma); in Malta it is the Matriculation Certificate (MATSEC), in Hungary it is called "érettségi bizonyítvány" roughly equivalent with the German phrase Zeugnis der Allgemeinen Hochschulreife as it originates from the Austrian-Hungarian Monarchy.
column2: El certificat de graduació equivalent a la República Txeca, Àustria, Polònia i altres països de l'Europa continental és el Matura ; mentre que a Anglaterra, Gal·les, Irlanda del Nord, Hong Kong, Singapur i les Índies Occidentals, té nivells A ; a Escòcia és de grau superior ; a la República d'Irlanda és el Leaving Certificate ; a Grècia i Xipre és l '" apolytirion " (una mena de títol de batxillerat); a Malta és el certificat de matriculació (MATSEC), a Hongria se l'anomena "érettségi bizonyítvány" aproximadament equivalent a la frase alemanya Zeugnis der Allgemeinen Hochschulreife ja que s'origina a partir de la monarquia austrohongaresa. A Austràlia, el certificat de graduació atorgat als estudiants de secundària és el Certificat d'Educació Secundària Sènior (SSCE). No obstant això, el nom de SSCE varia d'un estat a un altre.

column1: In India various states name it differently.
column2: A l'Índia diversos estats el denominen de manera diferent.

column1: Each Indian state has its own examination board, some individual states having their own entrance test system.
column2: Cada estat indi té el seu propi tribunal d'exàmens, alguns estats tenen el seu propi sistema de proves d'entrada. La superació de l'examen especificat capacita l'estudiant per accedir al programa de pregrau d'una universitat.

column1: Passing the specified examination qualifies the student to enter into undergraduate program in a university.
column2: Per exemple, als estats d' Andhra Pradesh i Telangana, això es coneix com Board of Intermediate Examination (BIE). Per a programes professionals, especialitzats i institucions amb bona reputació, hi ha proves d'accés. Per a l'enginyeria, hi ha un examen conjunt d'accés d' enginyeria a tots els nivells de l'Índia.

column1: For example, in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana this is known as Board of Intermediate Examination (BIE).
column2: Per a estudiants de pregrau metges MBBS programes hi ha una prova nacional de selecció i entrada conegut com NEET-UG nacional de selecció i prova de l'entrada dut a terme a tota l'Índia. També hi ha un examen de tot l'Índia realitzat per la Junta Central d'Educació Secundària CBSE, la certificació es coneix com a Certificat Secundari Superior (HSC).

column1: Occasionally, schools (especially berufsorientierte Gymnasien) offer vocational subjects such as pedagogy, business informatics, biotechnology and mechanical engineering.
column2: En algunes parts d'Alemanya, els estudiants poden preparar una presentació, fer treballs d'investigació o participar en un concurs i poden fer exàmens orals addicionals per aprovar l' Abitur si l'examen escrit és deficient. Abans de la reunificació, els exàmens Abitur es feien localment a Alemanya Occidental, però Baviera ha dut a terme exàmens centralitzats ( Zentralabitur ) des de 1854. Després de la reunificació, la majoria dels estats de l'antiga Alemanya de l'Est van continuar els exàmens centralitzats i, a principis del segle XXI, molts estats van adoptar els exàmens centralitzats.

column1: The Kultusministerkonferenz (KMK) of several states expanded the exams to scientific subjects and the social sciences.
column2: El Kultusministerkonferenz (KMK) de diversos estats va ampliar els exàmens a temes científics i ciències socials.

column1: The physics and chemistry exams include an experiment that must be performed and analyzed.
column2: Els exàmens de física i química inclouen un experiment que s'ha de realitzar i analitzar.

column1: Each semester of a subject studied in the final two years yields up to 15 points for a student, where advanced courses count double.
column2: Cada semestre d'una assignatura estudiada en els darrers dos anys obté fins a 15 punts per a un estudiant, on els cursos avançats tenen un doble. Els exàmens finals es compten per quatre. El sistema exacte de puntuació depèn del Bundesland, en què es pren Abitur.

column1: The final examinations each count quadruple.
column2: Els estudiants amb una puntuació inferior a aquest mínim fracassen i no reben un Abitur . Hi ha algunes altres condicions que l'estudiant també ha de complir per rebre l' Abitur : cursar cursos obligatoris en matèries seleccionades i limitar el nombre de notes no superades en assignatures bàsiques. Finalment, els estudiants sovint tenen l'opció d'ometre alguns cursos de la seva puntuació composta si han pres més cursos del mínim exigit.

column1: Percentage of jobholders holding Hauptschulabschluss, Realschulabschluss or Abitur in Germany:[8]
column2: Percentatge d'empleats que ocupen llocs sostenint Hauptschulabschluss , Realschulabschluss o Abitur a Alemanya: [1]

column1: Education in Germany Abitur after twelve years
column2: Educació a Alemanya Abitur després de dotze anys

column1: The Zeugnis der Allgemeinen Hochschulreife ("certificate of general qualification for university entrance"), often referred to as Abiturzeugnis ("Abitur certificate"), issued after candidates have passed their final exams and have had appropriate grades in both the last and second last school year, is the document which contains their grades and formally enables them to attend university.
column2: El Zeugnis der Allgemeinen Hochschulreife ("certificat de qualificació general per a l'accés a la universitat"), sovint anomenat Abiturzeugnis (" Certificat Abitur "), expedit després que els candidats hagin aprovat els exàmens finals i hagin obtingut les qualificacions adequades tant l'últim com el segon curs passat, és el document que conté les seves qualificacions i els permet formalment assistir a la universitat . Així, engloba les funcions tant d'un certificat de graduació escolar com d'un examen d'accés a la universitat. [1] El terme oficial a Alemanya d'aquest certificat d'educació és ; la contracció Abi és freqüent en l'ús col·loquial.

column1: Thus, it encompasses the functions of both a school graduation certificate and a college entrance exam.[1]
column2: [2] Aquest nombre, que reflecteix els que superen el tradicional Abitur a l'institut, és, però, inferior al recompte total. Sumant (per al 2012) els 51.912 estudiants que van obtenir el Hochschulreife a escoles de formació professional, aquest nombre total augmenta a 357.084. Si també s'afegeixen els que obtenen la Fachhochschulreife (144.399 el 2012), el total dels que van obtenir el dret a estudiar a una universitat o una Fachhochschule és de 501.483 (2012).

column1: From 1967 to 1973 Reich was a scientific assistant at the Research Institute of the Deutsches Museum in Munich and the Institute for the History of Mathematics and Natural Sciences at the Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich, where in 1973 she and Helmuth Gericke graduated.[1][2] In 1980 she completed her time in Munich, publishing The development of tensor calculus, in 1994 in a revised form as a book.[3]
column2: El 1981 va representar el Departament d'Història de la Ciència de la Universitat d'Hamburg . [5] El 1982 es va convertir en professora associada i el 1988 professora d'Història de les Matemàtiques a la Universitat de Stuttgart . [6] Des del 1994 fins a la seva jubilació va ser professora a l'Institut d'Història de les Ciències Naturals, Matemàtiques i Enginyeria de la Universitat d'Hamburg, on va succeir Christoph J. Scriba com a directora.

column1: Reich is a corresponding member of the Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities.[1]
column2: Reich és membre corresponent de l' Acadèmia de Ciències i Humanitats de Göttingen. [1]

column1: Maß, Zahl und Gewicht: Mathematik als Schlüssel zu Weltverständnis und Weltbeherrschung [Measure, number and weight: Mathematics as key to understanding and mastering the world] (with Menso Folkerts and Eberhard Knobloch, VCH, Acta Humaniora, Weinheim, 1989)[7] Die Entwicklung des Tensorkalküls: Vom absoluten Differentialkalkül zur Relativitätstheorie [The development of tensor calculus: From the absolute differential calculus to relativity theory] (Birkhäuser, 1994)[8] Im Umfeld der "Theoria motus": Gauß' Briefwechsel mit Perthes, Laplace, Delambre und Legendre [On matters having to do with the "Theoria motus": Gauss' correspondence with Perthes, Laplace, Delambre and Legendre] (Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2001)[9] Carl Friedrich Gauß und Russland: Sein Briefwechsel mit in Russland wirkenden Wissenschaftlern [Carl Friedrich Gauss and Russia: His correspondence with scientists working in Russia] (with Elena Roussanova, De Gruyter, 2012)[10] Carl Friedrich Gauß und Christopher Hansteen: Der Briefwechsel beider Gelehrten im historischen Kontext [Carl Friedrich Gauss and Christopher Hansteen:A correspondence between two scholars in historical context] (with Elena Roussanova, De Gruyter, 2015)[11]
column2: Maß, Zahl und Gewicht: Mathematik als Schlüssel zu Weltverständnis und Weltbeherrschung [Measure, number and weight: Mathematics as key to understanding and mastering the world] (with Menso Folkerts and Eberhard Knobloch, VCH, Acta Humaniora, Weinheim, 1989)[1] Die Entwicklung des Tensorkalküls: Vom absoluten Differentialkalkül zur Relativitätstheorie [The development of tensor calculus: From the absolute differential calculus to relativity theory] (Birkhäuser, 1994)[2] Im Umfeld der "Theoria motus": Gauß' Briefwechsel mit Perthes, Laplace, Delambre und Legendre [On matters having to do with the "Theoria motus": Gauss' correspondence with Perthes, Laplace, Delambre and Legendre] (Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2001)[3] Carl Friedrich Gauß und Russland: Sein Briefwechsel mit in Russland wirkenden Wissenschaftlern [Carl Friedrich Gauss and Russia: His correspondence with scientists working in Russia] (with Elena Roussanova, De Gruyter, 2012)[4] Carl Friedrich Gauß und Christopher Hansteen: Der Briefwechsel beider Gelehrten im historischen Kontext [Carl Friedrich Gauss and Christopher Hansteen:A correspondence between two scholars in historical context] (with Elena Roussanova, De Gruyter, 2015)[5]

column1: Tiburtius was one of the first two women to qualify as a doctor in imperial Germany.[1] Born on Rügen Island in Pomerania, Tiburtius was the youngest of nine children and daughter to tenant farmers.[2] Though she had intended to become a teacher, her brother Karl Tiburtius (an army physician) and sister-in-law, Henriette Hirschfeld-Tiburtius (the first woman dentist in Germany) encouraged Tiburtius to pursue medicine.
column2: Tiburtius va ser una de les dues primeres dones que es van classificar com a metge a l' Alemanya imperial. [1] Nascut a l'illa de Rügen a Pomerània, Tiburtius era el més petit de nou fills i era filla d'agricultors. [2] Tot i que tenia intenció de convertir-se en professora, el seu germà Karl Tiburtius (un metge de l'exèrcit) i la seva cunyada, Henriette Hirschfeld-Tiburtius (la primera dona dentista d'Alemanya), va animar Tiburtius a dedicar-se a la medicina.

column1: Refused entry to German medical programs, Tiburtius studied medicine in Zurich, passing her examinations with distinction in 1876.
column2: En negar-se a ingressar als programes mèdics alemanys, Tiburtius va estudiar medicina a Zuric, passant els exàmens amb distinció el 1876.

column1: That year she also completed an internship as a doctor of internal medicine with the gynaecologist and obstetrician, Franz von Winckel in Dresden.
column2: Aquell any també va realitzar pràctiques com a doctora en medicina interna amb el ginecòleg i obstetra, Franz von Winckel, a Dresden .

column1: In 1877, Tiburtius established a women's clinic with her fellow student Emilie Lehmus (1841-1932) in Berlin-Mitte at Schönhauser Straße 23/24.
column2: El 1877, Tiburtius va establir una clínica per a dones amb la seva companya d' Emilie Lehmus (1841-1932) a Berlin-Mitte a la Schönhauser Straße 23/24.

column1: Despite sustained opposition, including several court injunctions and slander, their clinic attracted a large clientele.[3] In 1908, Tiburtius opened a Surgery Clinic for Women Doctors with her colleague Agnes Hacker, which deliberately accepted women patients lacking health insurance.
column2: Malgrat l'oposició sostinguda, incloent diverses ordres judicials i calúmnies, la seva clínica va atreure una gran clientela. [3] El 1908, Tiburtius va obrir una clínica de cirurgia per a dones metges amb la seva companya Agnes Hacker, que va acceptar deliberadament dones pacients que no tenien assegurança mèdica.

column1: The needy were provided medicine free of cost.
column2: A les persones necessitades se'ls proporcionava medicaments de forma gratuïta.

column1: Tiburtius was a member of the women's movement in Germany.
column2: Tiburtius era membre del moviment de dones a Alemanya.

column1: Throughout her career she advocated for women's education and the repeal of extant bans barring women from continued study.
column2: Al llarg de la seva carrera, va defensar l'educació de les dones i la derogació de les prohibicions existents que prohibeixen a les dones continuar l'estudi. En col·laboració amb Helene Lange i Minna Cauer, Tiburtius va ajudar a establir un programa de formació continuada de dos anys, o Realschule, a Berlín.

column1: In collaboration with Helene Lange and Minna Cauer, Tiburtius helped establish a two-year continuing education program, or Realschule, in Berlin.[4] Her Berlin-based clinic also dedicated energy to women's medical education.
column2: [1] La seva clínica amb seu a Berlín també va dedicar energia a l'educació mèdica de les dones. Quan es va retirar, Tiburtius va viatjar a Amèrica i al nord d'Àfrica ia tota Europa. Va publicar una autobiografia, Memòries d'un octogenari, sobre la seva infància a Rügen.

column1: Alison Watt (born 1957) is a Canadian writer, and painter born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Watt grew up in Victoria, British Columbia.
column2: Alison Watt (nascuda el 1957) és una escriptora i pintora canadenca nascuda a Winnipeg, Manitoba, i va créixer a Victoria, Colúmbia Britànica .

column1: She studied biology at Simon Fraser University and botany at the University of British Columbia.
column2: Va estudiar biologia a la Universitat Simon Fraser i botànica a la Universitat de Columbia Britànica .

column1: She has worked as Education Coordinator at the VanDusen Botanical Garden in Vancouver, a tour leader in Central and South America, and a naturalist aboard the west coast schooner Maple Leaf, sailing among British Columbia's Gulf Islands, Haida Gwaii, the Great Bear Rainforest, and Alaska.
column2: Ha treballat com a coordinadora d'educació al jardí botànic VanDusen de Vancouver, líder de turisme a Amèrica Central i del Sud, i naturalista a bord de la goleta Maple Leaf de la costa oest, navegant a les Illes del Golf de la Colúmbia Britànica, Haida Gwaii, la selva tropical de Great Bear, i Alaska .

column1: Watt's book The Last Island: A Naturalist's Sojourn on Triangle Island is a memoir about life and death on a remote seabird colony.
column2: El llibre de Watt The Last Island : A Naturalist's Sojourn on Triangle Island és una memòria sobre la vida i la mort en una remota colònia d'ocells marins.

column1: The book won the Edna Staebler Award in 2003.
column2: El llibre va guanyar el premi Edna Staebler el 2003. També és una poeta guardonada.

column1: She is also an award-winning poet.
column2: El seu primer llibre de poesia, Circadia, va ser publicat el 2006 per Pedlar Press de Toronto.

column1: Her first book of poetry, Circadia, was published in 2006 by Toronto's Pedlar Press.
column2: En aquesta col·lecció, escenes de la vida ordinària es desenvolupen en un teló de fons de cicles de llum, marees i temps, i intenten captar el lirisme dels processos de la natura.

column1: In this collection, scenes of ordinary life unfold in a backdrop of light cycles, tides, and weather, and attempt to capture the lyricism of the processes of nature.
column2: Alguns es troben en una estació d'Amazon Research i exploren la taxonomia i la diversitat. En d'altres, es mou la natura passant com a teló de fons per aprofundir més en el seu funcionament interior, sovint invisible, com la fotosíntesi i la pol·linització, per alliberar-les del llenguatge de la ciència.

column1: Some are set in an Amazon Research station and explore taxonomy and diversity.
column2: Watt ha il·lustrat els seus llibres publicats. Artista excel·lent, ha tingut moltes exposicions en solitari i en grup.

column1: In others, she moves past nature as a backdrop to delve more deeply into its inner, often invisible workings, such as photosynthesis and pollination, to release them from the language of science.
column2: El seu treball va des de botànics aquarel·lars formals que reflecteixen la barreja de ciència i art del seu fons, fins a grans semi- abstractes en acrílic. Ha impartit nombrosos cursos de pintura botànica al Malaspina University-College de Nanaimo. A més, ha ensenyat aquarel·la i pintura acrílica al seu estudi de Protection Island .

column1: She published her debut novel, Dazzle Patterns, in 2017.[1] The book was a shortlisted finalist for the 2018 amazon.ca First Novel Award.[2]
column2: Va publicar la seva novel·la debut, Dazzle Patterns, el 2017. [1] El llibre va quedar finalista al premi de primera novel·la amazon.ca 2018. [2]

column1: 2002 – "Edna Staebler Award for Creative Non-Fiction" for a Canadian writer's first or second book[3] Backwater Review poetry prize subTerrain magazine poetry prize Bliss Carman competition – 2nd place
column2: 2002 - " Premi Edna Staebler a la no-ficció creativa " pel primer o segon llibre d'un escriptor canadenc [1] Premi de poesia Backwater Review premi de poesia de la revista subTerrain Competició Bliss Carman : 2n lloc

column1: Sonja Anita Maria Bernadotte, Countess of Wisborg (born Haunz; 7 May 1944 – 21 October 2008) was the widow of Count Lennart Bernadotte, grandson of Sweden's King Gustaf V through his father, Prince Wilhelm, the king's second son.
column2: Sonja Anita Maria Bernadotte, comtessa de Wisborg (nascuda Haunz ; 7 de maig de 1944 - 21 d'octubre de 2008) va ser vídua del comte Lennart Bernadotte, nét del rei suec Gustaf V a través del seu pare, el príncep Wilhelm, el segon fill del rei.

column1: She managed the Mainau estate on Lake Constance in southern Germany which her late husband purchased in 1951 from his father.
column2: Va gestionar la finca de Mainau al llac de Constança, al sud d' Alemanya, que el seu difunt marit va comprar el 1951 al seu pare. La finca de Mainau serveix com a principal atracció turística del llac de Constança, amb elaborats jardins florals, una casa de papallones i unes vistes atractives del llac.

column1: The Mainau estate serves as Lake Constance's main tourist attraction, featuring elaborate floral gardens, a butterfly house, and attractive views of the lake. Bernadotte became the Count's second wife in 1972.[1][2][3]
column2: Bernadotte es va convertir en la segona esposa del comte el 1972. [1] [2] [3] Després de la mort del comte el 2004, Sonja Bernadotte es va convertir en la cap de la fundació que organitza les reunions del premi Nobel a Lindau, [4] una conferència científica que se celebra anualment a Lindau, que convida els guanyadors del premi Nobel a interactuar amb joves investigadors de tot el món.

column1: In 1969, Sonja met her future husband Count Lennart Bernadotte of Wisborg whilst she was working as his personal assistant.
column2: El 1969, Sonja va conèixer el seu futur marit el comte Lennart Bernadotte de Wisborg mentre treballava com el seu ajudant personal.

column1: Lennart was thirty-five years older than Sonja, to the very day—their birthdays were only one day apart.
column2: Lennart tenia trenta-cinc anys més que Sonja, fins al dia mateix; els seus aniversaris només estaven separats un dia.

column1: Lennart was married and the father of four adult children.
column2: Lennart estava casat i era pare de quatre fills adults.

column1: He divorced his wife of almost forty years, with whom his relations had been uneven for some years, in order to marry Sonja.
column2: Es va divorciar de la seva dona durant gairebé quaranta anys, amb qui les seves relacions havien estat desiguals durant alguns anys, per casar-se amb Sonja. El casament del comte Lennart i la comtessa Sonja va tenir lloc el 29 d'abril de 1972. La parella va tenir cinc fills junts:

column1: Jennifer Fallon (born 1959) is an Australian author of fantasy and science fiction.
column2: Jennifer Fallon (nascuda el 1959) és una autora australiana de fantasia i ciència ficció. També és empresària, formadora i consultora empresarial. Jennifer té un màster a la facultat d'Arts Creatives de QUT .

column1: She is also a businesswoman, trainer and business consultant.
column2: Jennifer, entrenadora d'informàtica i especialista en aplicacions en el seu “treball diari”, treballa actualment a la indústria de les TI i passa un mes cada any treballant a la base Scott de l'Antàrtida.

column1: Lion of Senet (2002) Eye of the Labyrinth (2003) Lord of the Shadows (2003)
column2: Lleó de Senet (2002) Ull del laberint (2003) El senyor de les ombres (2003)

column1: Stargate SG-1: Roswell (2007) (coauthored with Sonny Whitelaw)
column2: Stargate SG-1: Roswell (2007) (coautor amb Sonny Whitelaw )

column1: Baggage (2010) edited by Gillian Polack "MacReadie V The Love Machine" More Tales of Zorro "Yours and Mine" (2009) Australia's Legends of Fantasy (2009) edited by Jack Dann and Jonathan Strahan "The Magic Word" Chicks In Capes "Diary of a Superchick" (2010)
column2: Baggage (2010) editat per Gillian Polack "MacReadie V The Love Machine" More Tales of Zorro "Yours and Mine" (2009) Australia's Legends of Fantasy (2009) editat per Jack Dann i Jonathan Strahan "The Magic Word" Chicks In Capes "Diary of a Superchick" (2010)

column1: Jennifer Fallon was born in Melbourne, Australia and after living in Central Australia for a number of years, now resides in the South Island of New Zealand.
column2: Jennifer Fallon va néixer a Melbourne, Austràlia i després de viure a Austràlia Central durant diversos anys, ara resideix a l'illa del sud de Nova Zelanda . Ha venut més de 750.000 llibres a tot el món, incloses tres trilogies i una tetralogia.

column1: She has sold over 750,000 books world-wide, including three trilogies and one tetralogy.
column2: És publicada per Snapping Turtle Books a tot el món, a més d'alguns títols a través de Voyager Books a Austràlia, Tor i Random House als Estats Units, Orbit al Regne Unit, AST a Rússia, Heyne i Egmont a Alemanya i Luitingh Fantasy als Països Baixos. . També ha estat coautora d'una novel·la de lligam, Stargate SG-1: Roswell .
